reviewText:
It's a quality game, but it's lacking a few basic features, such as the ability to auto-connect multiple intersections in one go. Instead you have to connect each segment manually. It gets pretty tedious!

And then there's the lack of a planner mode. A mode that would allow you to lay out the city in advance without any costs incurred. This would have helped with basic zoning and planning. Instead, I end up spending nearly all of my starting budget on ROADS...just to chart the damn city.

It's a bit annoying at times. Especially that fake twitter thing. A simple status update window that you could close into a tab would have been better than having a persistent blue-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥-bird hovering over your monitor the whole time.

But if I had to pick a game between Cities: Skylines and Cities XXL, I would choose Cities: Skylines, because it's an actual, honest to goodness game release, and not a copy-paste scam.

reviewText:
I can't tell you how many times out of my almost 200 hours I've restarted cities as new mods came out and traveling around IRL gives me ideas on how to lay out a damn road. And now that After Dark came out...

125/10 I'm making a new city again :D

On a serious note:
I love the gameplay of C:S. The controls are smooth, the modding community is awesome (and I mean, it's up there with the Skyrim modding community for me, and that's really freakin high), it's the best City Builder that I've played, and I highly doubt anything can top it. Then CO/Paradox adds more to the game, and it just keeps getting better and better.

Long Live City: Skylines!

reviewText: First of all: There is no single negative review yet. Not. a. single. one.\n\nThis game is simply, what Simcity 5 tried to be. The game is a decent mix of the best features of Simcity 4, Simcity 5 and Cities XL. For such a complex product just after release the amount of bugs is very low, and they are actually minor bugs. Simcity 5 features better graphics, but you'll be compensated for that by a good perfomance and an overall highly addictive game. The interface is just great (with some minor flaws), and the economy is a bit too easy too handle. It's 9/10 and by far the best city building game there is. Worth every cent.

reviewText: Very relaxing game. Easy, satisfying and very pretty. I never sought beauty inside a city until now. Workshop items help you make anything from Victorian London to Coruscant. Very powerful features - first person view - individual doods simulation and generally a well made game.\n\nI'm struggling to find a conn here but here goes. The traffic. It takes waay too much time to sort out properly. It's not even challenging it's just not in the tempo of the game. For every 20 minutes you spend building a part of your city, you then must spend 40 min to sort all the little traffic indicator thingies to be green (green is good). It's just something that we could do without but then the game would truly be very easy.

reviewText:
Below you'll find a written and video impression on the game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FIQUDCTDYuU

Cities Skyline gives the player everything you would expect from a proper modern city builder game. It has expansive maps, detailed cities and population, intricate micro management, yet it's accessible and easy to pick up.

Graphically the game is a looker. With detailed models, atmospheric filtering effects, and all the little things happening when you zoom in, the game look and feels alive. The audio design is immersive with the hustle and bustle of the crowds and traffic pulling the player in. Though the music seems over dramatic and on default settings it's strangely loud, but it does the job at keeping the player company.

Mechanically the game can get deep when you learn all the details, yet the basics to get going is pretty easy. With that said, the game still requires a degree of self research as all the finer details in it's mechanics aren't always fully explained.

Overall Cities: Skylines is a very enjoyable city builder, and at it's core, every thing I wanted from a modern Sim City.

Pros:
- Easy to learn
- Lots of fine detail to micromanage
- Great looking, very immersive
- Supports mods
- Huge map to build on

Cons:
- Finer detail mechanics aren't always explained well
- Some quality of life issues could use smoothing out

Cities: Skyline hours played at recording: 22
Completion Status on Cities Skyline: N/A
This copy of Cities: Skyline was purchased on Steam

reviewText:
If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
This doesn't just hit a home run, Cities SKYLINES bats it out of the park into orbit and to the moon Alice... and then some.
9 Hours into this game and I just can't put it down.  NO LAG, NONE, ZIP, ZERO, this game runs SMOOTH (specs below).

Started my first city today, messed about for 5-15 minutes getting the feel, then threw that away to start fresh now knowing what I need to do.  Having been playing 'Simcity' since the SNES version was released around 92 or so...

Built roads, facilities, zoned as needed.  Plenty of options.  You purchase more map tiles as you go, they are part of your live city.  No loading/saving to access another tile.  This game is downright awesome with that expansion bit - they nailed it.  I mean NAILED IT.  This is the TRUE SUCCESSOR TO SIMCITY 4 DELUXE.  THIS IS WHAT SC2013 SHOULD HAVE BEEN.  I'll write this again so everyone can see it.

THIS IS THE TRUE SUCCESSOR TO SIMCITY 4 DELUXE, THIS IS WHAT SIMCITY 2013 SHOULD HAVE BEEN.  IF YOU LOVED SIMCITY 4 AND PLAY IT TO THIS DAY, BUY THIS.  ENTIRELY WORTH IT, VERY AFFORDABLE!

There was Simcity on the SNES and pc.  Then there was Simcity 2000 on DOS 6.x on the venerable amd 486 66 ...
Then there was Simcity 3000... but 2000 and 3000 didn't quite capture the magic that Nintendo put into the SNES version.  For so many years I kept that SNES and Simcity... and then Simcity 4 came out... it was good, but not until Rush Hour expansion was it great.  Rush Hour combined into the Original was also marketed as the Deluxe version.  Adding in the NAM mod to Simcity 4 deluxe made the game really awesome if you were into highway design, and really could excell at traffic management.  Cities XL was buggy, and laggy... and very vague (and therefor frustrating).  Cities XXL had promise but just did not deliver beyond multicore enhancements - it was generally everything (bad with the good) that XL was... re-wrapped into a new package.  Simcity 2013 had promise, but EA's greedyness and needless DRM and small city sizes/day 1 bugs really got the game off to a bad start.  You just couldn't build to your imagination's content like you could in Simcity 4 Deluxe - beyond the initial degridding.  Simcity 2013 was like a demo, a demo of something that could have been so awesome...  but last week... last week I heard some bad news.
Maxis, to us City-Building afficianados - was something quite dear - Maxis was shuttered.  The Sims (EU studio) live on, but Simcity, as we know it, was official pulled off life support and pronounced dead... and know I know why.

This game.  GOD BLESS THESE DEVS, SKYLINES NAILS IT.  EVERYTHING.  5/5!!!

There is SO much realism packed into this game, and many things I did not expect.
Traffic management? Check!
Ability to build with realism using roads/avenues/bypasses to hearts content? Check!
Highways, offramps/onramps buildable?  Check!
Multilevel bridge over bridge stuffs for super-snazzy interchanges?  Check! (Roundabout, cloverloaf, diamond, trumpet, freeform entirely -not just PREFABS only, if you like - your imagination and the space available is your only limit)
Large expansion of the city as needed?  Check! (more with MOD support)
64bit exe and NO memory leaks?  Check!
GREAT graphics (for a city builder)?  Check!  [Directx 11 video card required under Windows!]
Sufficient sound feedback and decent music?  Check!  (Music in non-intrusive, sound fx I have no complaints on)
Good play control/movement/UI design?  Check!
Mod support?  Well, not yet - but devs are promising it!
Healthcare AND deathcare? EEK!  Check!
Trains for passengers AND freight?  Check!
Seaports for passengers AND freight?  Check!  (improves industrial demand)
Airports to attract more tourists and connect you better to the outside world (and their money!!!)? Check!
Ability to creat custom maps and a terrain editor (and importing greyscale heightmaps)? Check!
Ability to build in sunny tropical climate, or the more northern latitudes (custom gfx, sun angle)? Check!
Broad range of options to customize the game to your hardwares ability/disability?  Check!
Alternative ways to solve the many problems you face, and the ability to see you have them? Check & double Check!!!
Game breaking bugs?  Nope - not in over 9 hours into it... not anything I can see. No CTDs, no glitchyness, nothing.
I could go on and on...  58,000+ people in the city, 6 million in the treasury and making a good income monthly.
I just can't seem to want to stop playing or get bored of this... I am absolutely in shock at how good this game is.

Simcity 4 Diehards, This is the game WE have been waiting for - do NOT hesitate!  NO REGRETS HERE!
THIS GAME IS NOT AND IS NOT AFFILIATED WITH CITIES XL OR CITIES XXL IN ANY WAY/SHAPE/FORM, OTHER THAN IT BEING A CITY BUILDER, A GOOD ONE AT THAT, A REALLY REALLY GOOD ONE.


There are only TWO reasons you should not buy this game.
1.) If you cannot afford it.  The price IS very reasonable - VERY REASONABLE.
2.) If you have a video card that is not capable of DirectX 11.  Do not use Intel video, it's glitchy.
That said, those on Intel-based laptops, you need to force this game to use the dedicated AMD or NVIDIA gpu, otherwise it will be slow and glitchy defaulting to the laptop's Intel gfx.  You can do this from inside AMD Catylist, or Nvidia Control Panel.  You can find these solutions in the discussion forums here on Steam.  INTEL GFX IS NOT SUPPORTED.


As stated above, hardware specs are here:
i7 4790k @ 4.6ghz on Asus Maximus Hero VII Z97 Chipset motherboard
16gb 2400mhz ram (8gb x2) corsair dominator
Asus Radeon 7850 2gb gddr5 [1ghz core] video card with Direct CU II cooling (the don't-ever-hear-it cooler)
Dual Toshiba SSD drives in Raid 0 for OS & Games, for quick loading (almost zero load times. maybe a second or two)
Soundblaster X-fi Titanium pro soundcard
Fractal Arc XL case with Seasonic 750 watt PSU, and Phanteks somethin'-14 red cooler

I listed everything in the event someone wants to dupe the whole hardware config, game runs AWESOME.  NO LAG on HIGH settings.

Seriously, get this game now.  You'll be glad you did.   The devs really got this one right.  Finally, A SIMCITY 4 REPLACEMENT!

If you're a small kid with no money, do some extra chores for money!  Paint the dog, wash the lawn, mow the hedges, trim the carpet, vacuum the dishes, sweep the walls, scrub the garden, tiedye your white kittycat, ANYTHING to make money to buy this game (actually forget the bit with the cat, that might get you grounded, or worse, clawed and grounded).

Can't wait to see what the NAM team does with this one :)

--Cheers guys and good luck!  ... now if I can just kill that annoying little blue bird...

***Laptop users DON'T forget if you have intel GFX to make sure this game uses the AMD or NVIDIA GPU!  Desktop users should be just dandy as this issue won't happen.  AGAIN, INTEL GFX IS NOT SUPPORTED AT THIS TIME/POSSIBLY EVER.

reviewText: It's more of a road network building simulator than a city simulator. All of the zones you zone and all of the buildings you build are there to drive traffic in & out of your city. 90% of your planning and building and organizing goes towards the road network, to the point of micromanaging and obsessing. 90% of the problems you will face when laying out your city will be road related.\n\nBuilding the city just involves dragging zones with a paint tool and plonking down service buildings like hospitals and schools. All the cities end up looking and feeling very, very similar. The cities are very easy to build and grow. The only real challenge you ever face is designing a road network that flows and is not chaotic. This is fine. This can be fun. This can be interesting, and challenging. But this does not qualify as a city simulator.

reviewText:
Almost an hour in and just cleared 1,000 population.

Have encountered no problems whatsoever.  No lag or stuttering.  No crashes.  No bugs that I've found.

Interface is intuitive.  Gameplay is smooth and enjoyable.  Graphics look great (once I figured out how to reduce the angle blur).

Forcing myself to take a break for lunch.  Most difficult thing I've done all week.
----------
Just cleared 16,000 population.  Don't know how long I've been playing.

Still no problems.  Except the dead people.  There just aren't enough hearses and I can't build another cemetary yet.  Because of the trash problem.  The downtown fill is full, and it has to be emptied before the roads can be upgraded.  I've got four incinerators running to get rid of all that old trash.  Not sure why we can't just do the same with the dead people...

Forcing myself to take a break for dinner.  Very very difficult to stop playing now.
----------
Steam says I've played for 12 hours now.  I don't remember what my town population is.

But it doesn't matter.  People are irrelevant.  Only highways and train lines matter.  Beautiful, flowing lines of traffic with graceful easements and interchanges.

I did find one problem.  Clicking on a public transport vehicle (bus, train, etc) allows you to edit that line.  Subway cars cannot be clicked.  They can be seen in the public transportation overlay, but vehicles are not clickable on that screen.  It's impossible to edit the color of a subway line.  It's very difficult to delete it.

Also, I named a dog.  It tried to go to high school.  Someone chased it away.  Then the building caught fire.  Probably unrelated...

reviewText:
You're into macro management more than micro management ?
You're fed up of small maps ? (*winks at SimCity fail*)
You just want to relax while watching your city grow on the plots you simply designed ?
Then this game is for you ! A combination of the good parts of one city sim with another along with new features not yet made in any of those sim.

The bad point ?
- Localization suffers some typos/mistakes here and there, but it's still alright.
- Tunnels can't be made ... A mod to fix that ? *winks at modders*
- No building customization (giving it a continent style over another) ... Again, modders are there for that !

The good point ?
- Even after 4 hours, I still didn't fill the map and yet I could expand it more.
- Easy to understand.
- Traffic sim is quite alright, even though vehicles sometimes don't use all the road lanes for some reasons.
- Limitation ? What's that ? You're limitless ! Even doing a highway across your city is possible if you wanted to. (Although I don't see the point of doing it ...)

reviewText:
Best sim city type game since Sim City 4 Rushhour,  without question.  Obviously that does not say much when you compare what has come out since SC4 but still it is a great game.  Roads that are curvable, the ability to make your own buildings (think BAT tool in SC4 but a ton easier to figure out and use), custom bus lines, custom train lines, custom subway lines, taxis, ferry service, expandable roads, click and follow cars/pedistrians ...

It is not perfect mind you, the ability to bulldoze and flatten land does not exist (well it does on slopes with low % grades, but you want to flatten a mountain, that is not happening as no option to do it).

Also, once you reach 8 expansions of your city limits that is it.  No option to buy land past that (at least that I have found).  That said 8 extensions is a lot but would be nice to build more.  Right now I have a city at 110K population though it has been there for a while.  Thing is there is a huge online community that has gives tons of FREE downloadable content which makes the game interesting.  Currently I am on 92 plus hours and still loving it.  Just downloaded the expansion AFTER DARK (that costs money in case you were wondering) but it gives more eye-candy and transport options.

I currently give it an 8.5/10 which says a lot as it is rare I  ever give a game 8 or higher.

reviewText:
I've played 10 hours and I have seen everything the game has to offer.

There's next to no challenge is this game, once you get your city of the ground. After that, it is chugging out more zones for the city to grow.
People complaining about not enough healthcare? Dump another hospital somewhere in the vicinity and the issue is solved. Once your city is going money is no longer an issue.
This cycle repeats until you are too bored to continue.

The only interesting and difficult part is managing your traffic, which is somewhat annoying since you need to reach a certain population milestone before you can start building highways and such, making it hard to plan your infrastructure in advance.

There's also this amazing feature of the game (or maybe Unity) eating up as much RAM it can get its hands on. My system has 6GB of RAM and Cities: Skylines decided it should use 4GB of that storing god knows what. Chrome even had to move all of my tabs to the pagefile to make room for the game.

This game is fun, but only for a short bit. Don't pay much more than a tenner for this game.
voteText: 15 of 27 people (56%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It really was a fun game, but it quickely devolved in to a shallow, unchallenging experience.

Once you learn the tricks on how to organize your city it becomes pretty easy. The basic core is you have to manage the demands of your city while building new infrustructure. Sounds fun, except it really comes down to 3 demands: Housing, Industry, and Commercial. If the demand for housing goes up? Build a road and zone it for houses. How about Industry and Commercial? Do the same thing.

Sure, there are other things like resource management where you actually have to have the power, water/sewage, and other civil services. But a few hours in to my game I guess I found a sweet spot between growth and taxes because my cash flow exploded in to the millions before I even realized it happened. I could put hospitals and police on every street corner.

My city had become somewhat of a paradise, and it felt too easy.

reviewText:
I will not write a review destroying Sims city or XXL … This review is what you will experience in game :
**********************************************************************
This review is for people who are new to city building games.
*********************************************************************
Good things about skyline:

1)Smooth colouring, Identical icons, organized toolbar and clean screen. Unlike many other games, Cities skyline does not confuse you with similar icons or different varieties of colour all over the screen.

2) Game provides enough information for the user to keep everything under control and does not get lost.

3)Attractive design, good graphics and fun in-game Activities. Maybe by now, you think the game is a serious strategy game; which in fact it is to some degrees, but it does not lose its entertainment part. This game gives you so many small in-game activities and does not limit you to only designing your city. you can click on a random citizen or a car, get full information of them such as who owns the car, what is the type of car or where your citizen lives, works does or what is he doing. You can rename them to whatever you want and it does not get limited to cars and citizens, you can rename buildings, factories, shops, animals, parks and even streets. \n
4) I hardly can remember any bug or problem in game that bothered me ... good updates fixed everything

*************************************************************************
This game is everything that you need to build your dream cities.

one of the most important parts of this game is its community. the game has a tool that allows you to create or edit an existing building (that includes parks, houses and such) or even a map. You can come up with crazy ideas and make them happen. Even better you have chance to share it with others via steam workshop and let others enjoy too. Infact I made alot of buildings that people use them right now.

You can also get what others made and have fun with unique looking buildings
************************************************************************************

•	Your creativity and imagination are the only things that matter.  The game does not limit you with rules; in fact you are free to try different designs. With different tools you have option to create your city just as you like

*************************************************************************************
This game is a complete example of a good interface / well-designed game. It pretty much fulfils all expectations and meets all the principles of a good interface. It is impossible to think of a bad aspect in the game as everyone is satisfied by this game. Even if you have no experience with games; you can start Cities skyline with no fear of getting lost in the game and you can enjoy having a good time playing this game


Highly recommended

reviewText:
SimCity was one of the very first games I was ever really hooked on.  I vividly remember building cities in black-and-white on my dad's office Macintosh.  Since then I've jumped on pretty much any game that claims to be city-builder-ish.

And not since SimCity 4, over a decade ago, have I had this much fun building a city from scratch.

The scale of the space you can build in is great.  Starting with 2km x 2km and eventually expanding out to 9km^2, you can build truly massive cities. What makes that scale even better is you can really divide up your metropolis in a number of ways.  From districts that can have individualized govt policies (legal pot, smoke detector ditribution), to localized city services that aren't connected to the larger grid.  The game gives you a ton of room to experiment.

The one big challenge though you'll face is transportation.  Building an effecient city grid of roads, public transit, trains & subways that doesn't have terrible choke points is difficult.  Use of elevated bypasses, rail corridors etc are difficult to plan as you don't get access to them until an hour or more into a game, so you may find yourself abandoning your initial city area to build up things properly" in a newly opened plot of land
date: then going back and bulldozing your original downtown to start it over again.\n\nBeyond the traffic challenge
recommended: it can at times be difficult to know why your city isn't growing.  Sometimes demand drops to 0 for no apparant reason
hoursPlayed: then 5 minutes later skyrockets again.  There's obviously something going on that's pushing down demand
voteText: but as a player it's hard to figure out some times.  A few patches to improve UI and reporting will no doubt solve this issue.\n\nIn the end
helpfulPercent: the traffic planning and the simulation feedback issues are pretty minor in the face of what's probably the most fun city sim since the glory days of Maxis.  And at what I'd consider a "budget" price point
votesHelpful: if you're a fan of the genre
votesTotal: this is a must-buy game."

reviewText:
I've really looked forward to this game. Feel like I can give an early impressions review.

Pros:

- Performance is very good, smooth, the camera never stutters. Have felt no slow-ups.
- Easy to pick up the nuances of the game.
- Pretty.
- Mods. And this will save the game (see cons)

Cons:
- I feel like there isn't much variety in types of buildings. The mods however should over time offer a massive amount of content and I feel like it's only a matter of that this comment becomes irrelevant.
- Small gripe, but why can't the different lines be different colours? I find it really confusing and quite finicky to create a bus line.
- Another small gripe, but the two different blues used for Offices and Light Commercial are too similar, I often click the wrong one.
- Not very...exciting? It's fun to play, its light hearted, its nice to kill a bit of time but after an hour or two I found myself logging out. Some sort of immersion is missing. There isn't that much do apart from expand your city, there's no trade (not that I have yet seen) for example. Maybe having some ghost AI" cities far on the horizon that you can't visit but see could be connecting to your city and then opening possibilities of trade would be really awesome and give more emphasis on feeling that you're part of a connected world. At the moment it just feels very isolated.
-----------------------------------------------

Overall
date: it's worth the money and fun to play even it's a bit shallower than I had hoped."

reviewText:
You can tell when a game is created by passionate artists and developers. This could be the SimCity 4 successor that we have been waiting all these years for. Everything that SC2k13 did wrong, Colossal Order tried to make right. City sizes are 9x bigger, and easily modded to 25x bigger than SC2k13. They didn't only make things better, they also introduced many new features such as districts, specialized industrial zones and dynamic water movement. Modding support is also a huge feature that is offered. The Steam Workshop has over 1000 mods, models and maps already online less than 24 hours after the release. There are a handful of requests for features that didn't make it to release, but the devs promised that they would continue working on this game to include as many new features as possible. (Such as road & highway tunnels, disasters and day/night cycles).

This is only the first day of the launch, and the game is already extremely stable, and looks beautiful.
I look forward to seeing what the devs and the mod community comes up with in the future!

This game was created by a small indie development team and look at what they produced. I highly recommend this game to anyone who felt disappointed with SimCity and wants to play a genuine city simulator that has the fun of previous versions, but the new features that modern gamers want to play.

reviewText:
Excellent game. Feels a lot like SimCity 4, but with better graphics and better traffic simulation. It is by the people who made the City in Motion games, so not surprising. It leaves SimCity 2013 in the trash bin where it belongs.

My  current game has train lines going between isolated town areas, and a big city area. It feels more like a small country than a single city.

The negatives I have to mention are that there doesn't appear to be an undo" button once you do something
date: and there appears to be no way to reverse one way streets. You have to destroy them and rebuild them. Kinda silly.  Those are just small nitpicks though. The game is solid and is the first pre-order I haven't regretted."

reviewText:
Best city building game ever... and I don't just say that lightly. It has the depth and complexity of the best of the Sim City games mixed with sleek modern graphics.

Your City live breathes and evolves constantly through the game, as you grapple to keep it from falling into enviromental and economic disaster.

The only disadvantage to this game is the lack of unique disaster events, e.g earthquakes, that the Sim City franchise featured. However the developer has promised to patch them into the game.

With strong features, engaging and complex game play as well as Steam Workshop mod support, Cities Skylines in everything that the recent Sim City reboot should have been.

reviewText:
Easily the best city builder to come around in a long time. It also does alot to bring new wrinkles into the established formula. Being able to name and customize pretty much anything in the game is fantastic. And also having the ability to create separate districts within the city is a great addition. You can even set different policies within each district. Want an area with no smoking? You can do that. Want people to recycle? Click the checkbox.

Only thing I'd say that could be considered 'negative' would be that you can't take any loans out until you reach a population of 400+. So if you get a little overzealous when starting out (like I did), you might find yourself in a bind. You can take a Bailout, but then that disables being able to do certain things.

Overall I'm really enjoying the game, and I can see this being a top played for me for awhile.

reviewText:
I've really looked forward to this game. Feel like I can give an early impressions review.

Pros:

- Performance is very good, smooth, the camera never stutters. Have felt no slow-ups.
- Easy to pick up the nuances of the game.
- Pretty.
- Mods. And this will save the game (see cons)

Cons:
- I feel like there isn't much variety in types of buildings. The mods however should over time offer a massive amount of content and I feel like it's only a matter of that this comment becomes irrelevant.
- Small gripe, but why can't the different lines be different colours? I find it really confusing and quite finicky to create a bus line.
- Another small gripe, but the two different blues used for Offices and Light Commercial are too similar, I often click the wrong one.
- Not very...exciting? It's fun to play, its light hearted, its nice to kill a bit of time but after an hour or two I found myself logging out. Some sort of immersion is missing. There isn't that much do apart from expand your city, there's no trade (not that I have yet seen) for example. Maybe having some ghost AI" cities far on the horizon that you can't visit but see could be connecting to your city and then opening possibilities of trade would be really awesome and give more emphasis on feeling that you're part of a connected world. At the moment it just feels very isolated.
-----------------------------------------------

Overall
date: it's worth the money and fun to play even it's a bit shallower than I had hoped."

reviewText:
Surprisingly solid and refined game that is fun, has depth and feels very accessible. Lots of stuff to dig into, especially considering the price.

The game is not perfect (a bit on the easy side, lack of building variety, needs some events and/or disasters to break up the later game a bit), but still lots of fun - and mods already start addressing some of the problems and the developers are already promising free content patches.

Even in its current state, it's well worth the price of admission and a good city builder, the future potential is just the extra cherry on top.

reviewText:
After only 4 hours of this game I can say I am in love.

Positives

Huge maps (who ever came up with the idea to keep expanding your city limits should get a pay raise)

PLANNING TOOLS!

Districts (and of course you can do alot with them too)

Great Optimization

So much you can do with roads and pathways (Ramps, ramps everywhere)

Great community

easily moddable

Negatives

The two one way roads (connect to the outside world highway) at the start of the game can cause alot of problems with traffic (kind of annoying but in a way fun to work around)

Minor things (bugs,etc.)

Verdict
10/10 - how can it get any better?

Thank you paradox!

reviewText:
Cities: Skylines by Paradox Interactive is an iterative game. It grabs the majority of things it has on display from city building games in the past and makes up what is effectively a big playground for you to play around in. Nothing is spared from Cities XL, Cities in Motion (a previous Paradox title) and the Sim City franchise. The reason for its hype and stature is not that it has all these things in it. All of these functions and mechanics have been on display before.

It is well received by city building fanatics and casual players because it does these things *well*. Sim City 4 has many quirks, and despite the nostalgia surrounding it, that game has some extremely dated mechanics that detract from the experience. Sim City 2013 came around and people wanted a way to enjoy the good old stuff from Sim City 4 in a better, more enjoyable, more modern fashion. Needless to say it didn't live up to its promises, everyone twelve feet from the nearest rock should be filled in on that by now. Cities XL is a buggy mess that breaks apart merely a few hours in playing it. 'Skylines' yanks the best mechanics from these games and others and pull them off the way they should have been pulled off. No essential content is locked away behind a paywall. The cities are as large as they should be -and should you want even larger cities, the surprisingly smooth modding element of this game makes it easy to expand the default 6 tile plot size to 25 provided your PC can handle it- with no holds barred.

Your traditional pieces of city building goodness are present here, for all to enjoy. The roads are satisfying to build and maintain, the statistics and logistics make sense unlike in Sim City to the game's best intentions, and the already mentioned mod support is a godsend. Tired of the tweeting bird that never wants to shut up? There's a mod to remove that. Unhappy with the fact that a structure isn't in the game? Download it from the steam workshop without even restarting the game.

It's not a very forgiving game, which you may discover if you're migrating from Sim City 2013. The difficulty mainly hangs on to the fact that this game makes sense. It's not always 100% dead on in terms of the bigger decimals and values it pushes, but compared to some of the more nonsensical things present in Sim City it's surprisingly accurate. The game definitely punishes you for doing a sloppy job as city manager. Prepare to have many headaches if you don't pay attention to where you put your water pipes, or if you don't have a backup power source when your power plant burns down because you didn't put a fire station anywhere close. That's on you, buddy.

No game is perfect, mind, and the game has legitimate pieces of content that isn't there as of writing this review, a proper way to terraform while in the city and make your own bodies of water being a glaring omission. Some parts of the game also don't make much sense without a proper tutorial, like the commute system which I can't figure out at all. I also don't think you should have to search Google to see if too many water pipes is going to be an issue, or how the water purification system functions. Considering how much Paradox cares about their customers tjough, these issues are insignificant to most when seeing just how well it all performs. My graphics card is six years old, and my processor isn't anything special, and I'm still surprised that six tile cities manage to run this good without a hitch on my system.

Anything less than stellar can either be patched by Paradox or simply modded in. As a base game it beats most, and at a £30 launch price it leaves a good taste in my mouth, and it should in yours too. With developer love and a high ability to mod it, this game is sure to be the de facto city builder for many years to come. The future is bright.

reviewText: This is a really fun game that i think the earlier sims should have been. The traffic mechanic is really well optimised although the flaw that i have found in the algorithm is that the cars are programmed to take the WIDEST road and not the most direct road, eg. If i have an industrial estate with 3 entrances, one a 2 lane 2 way road and the other is a 6 lane 2 way road, all the cars (or at least 90% of them) will take the 6 lane road as the cars think that taking the wider road is the better option as you can fit more cars onto them but when all the cars think that then they soon build up and you have to rethink all your roads... But thats what i enjoy, finding problems in my roads and then spending the time to fic, fix and fix again to make to they work as best the can! Also i have found that more entrances and exits DO NOT make the traffic smoother as more roads mean more junctions with more traffic lights, slow the cars down so 1 entrance is more effective than 17.  I hope you enjoyed my little chat about this game but for the price, I highly reccomend this game to everyone!

reviewText:
This is a good game. I would say that many of the comparisons to the latest Sim City aren't all that helpful because they seem to view this game as far superior to that game when there are lots of tradeoffs that both games have made.

Data visualization in this game is somewhat poor in comparison to Sim City 2013. Cities: Skylines also doesn't have different wealth classes, a highly ambiguous Land Value system along with a slightly difficult to follow specialization system, and the user interface is... borderline Cities XL bad. It's also not entirely bug free with massive traffic clogging occurring at entrances to the city (much like issues that plagued Sim City 2013). Traffic agents in this game aren't all that smart and there are tons of quirks that make it frustrating to play at times: buildings becoming abandoned because a dead person wasn't picked up, really? It would help if all of the hearses didn't crowd around one building--like the fire engines crowd around a single burning building (again, an issue that occurred in Sim City 2013). The notification system is also completely useless and just serves as an obnoxious distraction from gameplay.

The bad aside, I like this game. I'm not forced to stop playing after a few hours because of some bug or because my city is already bursting out of its boundaries. The system of buying more land plots to expand your city is ingenious and somehting that I'm surprised no one thought of before. I love the public transit system and all the little nuanced features it has though it can be a little daunting to set up at first. There are lots of little features that really help make this game s city builder worth playing.

Overall, I feel like this game is almost like a Microsoft product: trying to be all things while never succeeding at doing a single thing perfectly well. It could use more polish (they're already releasing patches), but is definitely a recommended title for any avid city builder.  I've found that most reviewers are just happy that they have a city builder that isn't Sim City 2013, but I'd say that there are many things that that game did very well that Cities: Skylines doesn't and vice versa. If I were to rate Cities: Skylines, I would give it a 7.5/10 -- Good, but not great with its share of flaws.

reviewText:
The City Building Game No One Asked For - But The City Building Game We Deserved
tl;dr - If you like city building games, you should buy this - without question. If you've played the classics then you'll be right at home and if you're new to the genre, this is a great starting point. There's a couple of teeny tiny issues that are mostly opinion-based but nothing that breaks the game. 9.5/10

First and foremost, it's not without its flaws - but the flaws are quickly lost in the charm and incredible achievement that the developers attained with this game.

The immediate sense of creative freedom you get with Skylines is apparent the moment you start on your first lot. Yes, the appearance of the dreaded 'city boundaries' might remind some of the restrictions of other city building games, but once you start laying road and placing zones, you realize the scale fits perfectly, usually having you spend a good few hours in your first square alone. Then you discover you can buy more plots.

The gameplay is very reminiscent of other city builders - no point trying to fix what isn't broken. Although I'd say that Skylines easily fixes some attempted mechanics that other city builders attempted in the past. The agent system - where you can follow every individual person and vehicle (even animal, if you want) - might still not be perfect, things still very 'processed' whereas in real life things a little more chaotic, it still works well enough. A common complaint is traffic, but that's not the agents' fault, but more likely the fault of the road layout.

Speaking of which, this is probably the biggest challenge of the game. Managing traffic will likely take more of your time than zoning and controlling land value. Thankfully the game offers you a massive set of tools to best manage your roads, the only limit is your imagination~. The game will also intelligently place roads as best it can, meaning you'll usually always be able to make a junction even if the angle is a little tight.

One of the few little caveats that I certainly run in to is pipe placement. Power lines and pipes need to be placed manually - the former never too much an issue since buildings link power between themselves in a small radius, connecting to each other so long as they're close enough. Water and sewage pipes, however, need to be placed manually every time you expand your city. Maybe I'm just lazy, but it's always easy to forget when power takes care of itself.

Perhaps the modding community may have a solution - as this game is highly moddable. The in-game asset creator allows people to import models and customize buildings to help diversify the rather small set of preset buildings - as well as powerful scripting mods to add entirely new features (of writing, one of the most popular mods is the auto-bulldoze mod).

All in all, if you've been looking for a city builder to sink your time in to and thoroughly enjoy, Cities: Skylines won't do you wrong. The price point is fantastic for a game this entertaining and as much as people might draw comparisons to other city builders, I personally think Skylines can very well stand on its own in the genre.

reviewText:
This is a difficult one to write. Getting straight to the point, Cities Skylines takes the new SimCity back to basics, and nails those basics spot on. This includes huge maps, a terrain editor, lots of transportation options and competant graphics. In doing this, it has also taken steps back.

This game comes with the same flaws that the older games had: you would lay some roads, zone an area, and place one of each service in the centre of that area. You would repeat this over and over again. Whereas in SC 2013, they added modular buildings and specialisations to mix up the gameplay (such as adding casinos with different room types for wealth levels), this new game is purely zoning and placing the same buildings over and over. Even the specialisations are actually reskins of the industrial zones, and are zoned with the same tools. They offer little difference to the gameplay.

If you want huge maps, and are simply interested in designing a city for the sakes of it, then I can recommend to you this game very easily! It has plenty of tools to make your perfect city look" like a perfect city. But

recommended: has more content and is less repetitive
hoursPlayed: then SimCity is your best bet. For example

reviewText:
Vanilla Game
Is the best city builder since Sim City 4, if from a City Builder you like something like the classic Sim City and not like Tropico, Anno etc... So the focus is transport and you can build the city as you want because the game is almost to easy. Is easy to get money but your city will suffer from a chain of problems that you can address by adding resurces, reshaping roads and smoothing trafic. Anyway no metter how many problem the city does have is almost inpossible that your citizen become unahppy; and because criminality is linked to happyness police is not really necessaty. I suggest to give a try to the vanilla game before installing any mod/map

Mods
The mod can already totally reshape the game experience: you can download tons of additional buildings both ploppable or growable, you can change the point of view to street level, alter the colur scheme and resolution, alter the interface (tranforming Chirpy in a scroll text just like the one on SC4), alter games rules to increase or decrease the challenge.
Maps are also great: usign the site terrain.party you can download a map from your favourite location in the world, and since the map in the game is preaty big you can recreate a small city and its sourrounding. The water simulation express its true potential when you try to add a river in your custom map.

TL:DR
A great Game, maybe non perfect and not particularry challenging, but surely a great platform with a lot of potential for modding or expansion

reviewText:
Well what can I say. It's a big middle finger to EA's SimCity. There is so much more complexity and entertainment to be found in this game over SC.
I've only played 18 Hours of it so far and in that time I've roamed around Los Santos from GTA 5, Venice, France, UK and Gotham.
I've ruined two worlds by accidentally polluting the water and putting thousands of people in hospital running up my debt and now finally after those 18 hours I've finally got the hang of the game and I'm now safely running a 30k pop world and rising.


PROs
- Higher learning curve required over SM
- In-depth tax, resource management, budget system
- Mods
- Large Landscape
- Custom Maps

CONs
- No autosave feature
- Mods disable achievements
- Manual Bulldozer

Possible future patches could include the cons listed.
An autosave feature would be a godsend, every so often my PC decides to randomly cut off for no reason and if I haven't sayed for quite some time, that's a huge chunk of my time wasted as I'll have to do it all over again.
Some mods actually benefit the game without deteriorating from the experience (unlimited cash) such as a the autosave mod.
Having to manually click each indivual road or house item can over time become tedious, automating this like the Bulldozer in SM would be beneficial

reviewText: Paradox and Colossal Order give us the best city builder since Sim City 2000. While some may not like Paradox's DLC model (and let's be honest, it can be a bit intimidating for new players), CSL offers loads of awesome content out of the box for a very affordable price. Micro-managers will love the ability to fine tune almost every aspect of their cities, from the names of city districts all the way down to following a single citizen around throughout his day. While there is a bit of a learning curve and the in-game tutorial is rather lacking (a hallmark of Paradox games) there are many youtubers and an official wiki that can help get you up to speed. A great, affordable buy for pretty much anyone!

reviewText:
Cities: Skyline is a city-simulator not unlike its Sim City predecessors. Unlike EA's most recent installment, however, Skyline understands what its consumers want. None of that token multiplayer online-connection ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t; it's just a quality city simulator with excellent modding support and a quality developer.

I'll get the negatives out of the way first. One of the most annoying things is a Twitter knockoff that pops up on the top of your screen. Yes, it keeps you informed on what the citizens are thinking but not nearly as intuitively as one would like. Plus, it's annoying. Outside of that, there are a few other things here and there; buildings get abandoned like no one's business, and I would much rather have some sort of construction crew I could hire rather than having to go through and manually bulldoze each individual abandoned property. The public transit systems, while useful, don't provide the best feedback on how popular they are or how efficiently they are functioning. Finally, the roads could use a bit less liberal snapping; it's very hard to keep things straight, and you end up wasting space.

That might seem like a lengthy negative paragraph at a glance, but I'll be honest: it's just nitpicks here and there. The game is quality with incredible simulation: all your citizens can be tracked, and their cars can be clicked and observed extensively. And when they ask why the mayor is sitting in the back of their car? Who cares. You are the one true mayor. How dare they question the authority of your elected office?

There are a lot of nice touches to the game that make the cities you build feel vibrant and realistic. Water flow is key to maintaining a balance between pollution and your water supply, and the physics, while simple, are effective. The game isn't some casual time-waster either; forethought and budgeting are required to stay afloat. But if you don't want to worry about that, there's also auto-installed mods for things like unlimited money and full-unlocks. You can buy land for your city with each milestone you achieve through population growth, as well as gain upgrades to your buildings and districts. The game also runs very well, and the mechanics are very easily picked up--especially if you have experience with your classic city-management builder. If you don't like any of the maps, there is also a map creator you can use, which is fun to use if I do say so myself.

So all in all? This is a quality addition to the genre. It's accessible to newer players and refreshing to veterans, and if you are a fan of the genre, I would highly recommend it. The game is full of content, and new content is being added by the vibrant modding community. The developers treat the community with respect and appreciation (UNLIKE A CERTAIN OTHER COMPANY), and they are very actively involved, appreciating feedback and discussion among their forums. So yeah, there are a few faults here and there, but I would say this game is definitely worth it's price.
